you know, you should freeze anything before you put it into the freeze dryer. The point of freeze drying is sublimation: going from solid straight into gas. It prevents bubble forming. The freezer part of the freeze dryer is to collect sublimating water from the sample as ice in order not to reach (and maybe damage) the vacuum pump. And of course it helps to keep your material frozen.
If you don't freeze the material beforehhand, gases from the sample (it can be air, or evaporated H2O because of the vacuum) will expand inside of the solution - therefore forming a bubble.

The reason for the consistency of ballpoint ink is because of how the pens work, as the name suggests there's a metal (usually tungsten or even tungsten carbide) ball inside a brass cup which feeds it the ink, naturally because of the high pressure on the ball (all the weight of your hand on a tiny surface) it catches on the brass cup which doesn't allow it to move.
The ink is made to also function as a lubricant so that this doesn't happen and the ball can roll in the cup as you write, if there was watery Indian ink in the ballpoint pen it wouldn't lubricate the ball and it would get stuck as you try to write.
